source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: growth specimens with various fabrication parameters were irradiated in a pressurized water reactor (PWR) to high fluences

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: Some of the growth specimens were exposed to a fast neutron fluence of up to 2.3×10²² cm⁻² (≥0.82 MeV) over a period of 10 years

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: At a temperature of 300°C during irradiation to fluences up to 7×10²¹ cm⁻² growth increases with increasing yield strength

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: Recrystallized material, which has a low yield strength, exhibits an increased growth rate at very high fluences (≳1×10²² cm⁻²)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: At temperatures in the range of 330 to 350°C, the growth depends on the grain size, especially below 2 μm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: and on the carbon-content

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: The effect of yield strength on growth was less at 330 to 350°C than at 300°C probably because of an irradiation-induced recovery

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: TEM showed that an irradiation-induced formation of dislocations with a c-component occurs at neutron fluences ≥9×10²¹ cm⁻²

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: whereas dislocation loops or fine precipitates or both form at lower fluences

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: The intermetallic precipitates observed in the microstructure of the unirradiated, initial material exhibit two types of intermetallics

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: One type contains (Fe+Cr+Zr) and the other type contains only (Fe+Zr)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: At ≤300°C the (Fe+Zr)-type intermetallic precipitate dissolves at neutron fluences above 5×10²¹ cm⁻²

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: The (Fe+Cr+Zr)-type precipitates become more and more amorphous and release iron to the matrix resulting in a decreasing Fe/Cr ratio

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: The diameter and the number of the precipitates decrease with increasing neutron fluences at this temperature

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: Only a few small precipitates can still be observed after a neutron fluence of 1.5×10²² cm⁻²

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk1
evidence_span: At temperatures above 340°C the size of intermetallics increases because of irradiation enhanced ripening

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk2
evidence_span: The materials comprise Zircaloy tubes from various fabrication routines with different final heat treatments, for example, stress relieving (SR), partially recrystallizing (PR), and fully recrystallizing (RX)
process_step: stress relieving (SR), partially recrystallizing (PR), fully recrystallizing (RX)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk4
evidence_span: two types of intermetallics were detected. One is the normal ZrFeCr intermetallic with a Fe/Cr ratio of 1.9 to 2.5, which is known to be Zr(FeCr)₂, the other is a ZrFe intermetallic, which is either Zr₂Fe or Zr₃Fe

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk4
evidence_span: In β-quenched specimens only the Zr(FeCr)₂ precipitate with a Fe/Cr ratio of 1.8 to 3.6 was found

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk4
evidence_span: Irradiation at 290 to 300°C changes the composition and the morphology of the ZrFeCr-type precipitate

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk4
evidence_span: At the highest fluence the precipitate became amorphous

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk4
evidence_span: preferential release of iron results in a decrease in the Fe to Cr ratio from about 2.5 to 0.4

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk4
evidence_span: At lower fluences (5×10²¹ cm⁻²) this change of morphology and composition occurs only at an outer rim of about 70 nm

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk4
evidence_span: Adjacent to the intermetallic, a peak in the iron concentration profiles is seen

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk4
evidence_span: Irradiation at 340 to 390°C causes only a small reduction in the Fe to Cr ratio and does not cause a change from crystalline to amorphous

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk4
evidence_span: Postirradiation annealing at 500°C after irradiation at 300°C to 1.7×10²² cm⁻² (≥0.82 MeV) increases the Fe/Cr ratio, again compared to as-irradiated, and transforms the structure from amorphous back to crystalline

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk4
evidence_span: Zr-Fe type of precipitate does not shrink like the ZrFeCr precipitate because of a release of the transition metals from the edge but forms lamellas of zirconium within the precipitate and stays crystalline

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_041_chunk4
evidence_span: Postirradiation annealing at 500°C after irradiation at 300°C to 1.7×10²² cm⁻² causes a precipitation of 0.03- to 0.25-μm large intermetallics
